Author: Heavy metal pirate#4232
Content: Hi guys. Can someone please tell me how to iterate in data like this? ({:foo bar}, {:bar foo}) i have been struggling for hours with it

Author: arichiardi#2361
Content: @Heavy metal pirate what should your data outup look like? Basically a map is a seq of key/values so

Author: arichiardi#2361
Content: You need one map for the outer, one iteration for the individual maps

Author: hswick#4417
Content: @Heavy metal pirate ```clojure (map (fn [thing] (keys thing)) '({:foo "bar"} {:bar "foo"}))``` would be one way to iterate over your data

Author: hswick#4417
Content: grr tried to do the fancy markup

Author: hswick#4417
Content:
```clojure 
(def list-of-things '({:foo "bar"} {:bar "foo"}))
(map (fn [thing] (keys thing)) list-of-things)
```

Author: goomba#1378
Content: @Heavy metal pirate you trying to dig out the values or you want to concat them into a list or what?

Author: goomba#1378
Content:
```clojure
(def ms [{:a 0} {:b 1}])
(apply concat (reduce #(apply conj %1 %2) [] ms)) ;;=> (:a 0 :b 1)
```

Author: goomba#1378
Content: probably a better way to do that

Author: goomba#1378
Content: ü§î

Author: goomba#1378
Content:
```clojure
(->> ms
  (reduce #(apply conj %1 %2) [])
  (apply concat)
```

Author: goomba#1378
Content: I guess that's a _mild_ improvement

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content:
Hey guys, I just started using Clojure this week and I've fallen in love. I came from about 6 years of Java, 2 or so of Scala, and ~6 months of experimenting with Haskell.
I originally picked up Clojure for the sole purpose of web-stuff, but tbh now it's my favorite language.

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content:
That said I have some questions.
Where does clojurescript come into play?

Author: john#2563
Content: Well, aren't you just the ideal candidate üòâ

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: I am üòÆ?

Author: john#2563
Content: Clojurescript is for when you desire Clojure-like syntax and _some_ Clojure-like semantics, while working in JS land.

Author: john#2563
Content: Many of JS' limitations carry over to CLJS

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: I went to Clojure desperately trying to avoid Javascript, and I found a happy spot with things like Compojure, Hiccup, etc

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: But I'm wondering if I'm shooting myself in the foot

Author: john#2563
Content: I don't think so. Designing everything server-side, in CLJ, is still a very valid path.

Author: john#2563
Content: SPAs and heavier client-side features are just going to be easier in CLJS

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: The idea me and my friends are going to be working on is quite similar in presentation to reddit

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: The ideas we want to throw in and the stuff behind it is different, but the whole.. "package" I guess is just very reddit-y

Author: john#2563
Content: You can def do the whole thing without dipping into CLJS, if you don't want to yet.

Author: john#2563
Content: And certain aspects of your reddit-like thing are going to require server-side coordination anyway.

Author: john#2563
Content: Like, authentication and authorization over certain resources

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: üòÖ I'm having lots of fun, but having never done any web-stuff and having never used clojure is making this one hell of an experience, in a good way

Author: john#2563
Content: Starting off, it's a bit of a firehose. Same as any other paradigm, but others are just more normalized.

Author: john#2563
Content: If try to imagine how hard Clojure would be if you didn't know Java. That's what CLJS will be like if you don't know JS.

Author: john#2563
Content: Knowing the host makes things quicker and easier to get started.

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content:
Makes sense, but tbh Java didn't really help me with Clojure at all

Actually, whenever I try to relate it to Java I get hopelessly confused, but if I just "go at it" I guess it's wonderful

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: I want to say all my functional exploration helped me get here, but it's so foriegn that I can't even say that much

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: The Lispyness just felt incredibly intuitive

Author: john#2563
Content: from a certain perspective true. But error messages, for example. You'll be much more familiar with them than someone not familiar with java.

Author: john#2563
Content: and interop

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: That's true, error messages are kinda hellish I've noticed, and Java exp probs helps

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: Interop with objects from other libs is hell

Author: john#2563
Content: Java devs have much less trouble with interop

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: Native-clojure stuff comes like second nature, but using stuff I even know in Java is impossible

Author: john#2563
Content: and CLJ/CLJS are very pro-interop languages

Author: john#2563
Content: @Â±àÊâç hmm. lots of folks speak fondly of Clojure's interop with Java. I've found it to be pretty smooth, though I still have a few blind spots here and there.

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: I think I just fail to translate between Java and Clojure ways of thinking effectively

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: I kind-of loathe java and only use it because by this point I'd have to be a retard to not be great at it

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: Maybe Scala interop would be easier

Author: john#2563
Content: Algorithmically, yeah, you would usually produce far different solutions, and you wouldn't mix them. But in terms of building wrappers around existing java libs, people tend to be pretty happy with it.

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: One day I'll be a clojure wizard

Author: john#2563
Content: Remember though that anyone can invent new constructs with macros. Because it is infinitely extensible, every wizard can potentially be a noob tomorrow. There's no upper bound on the wizardry.

Author: john#2563
Content: _(if that's any consolation)_

Author: Â±àÊâç#4590
Content: Wise words mr wizard

Author: john#2563
Content: lol https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2Op3QLzMgSY

Author: john#2563
Content: love that wizard

Content: Was this recorded on an potato?

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: http://tonsky.me/blog/readable-clojure/

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: Sooooo, thoughts?

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: Don't agree with the `seq` bit. Or avoiding higher order function composition.

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: The asterisk for references isn't that bad an idea, but maybe not an asterisk. I dunno.

Author: goomba#1378
Content: Yeah, I had similar thoughts @Slackwise

Author: goomba#1378
Content: I understand his point that you can go overboard with the anonymous scripts and whatnot but as long as you keep your functions small and aren't doing side effects and have tests and adhere to your input/output contract I think mandating that you shouldn't user higher level functions, threading macros, maps/sets as functions, etc is really robbing you of a lot of the power/elegance of the language

Author: goomba#1378
Content: I mean... as an example... if I have a vector and then I want a sorted vector

Author: goomba#1378
Content: and then let's say I want to add one to each item in the vector

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: A key reason I like Clojure is its expressiveness.

Author: goomba#1378
Content:
```clojure
(let [v [2 3 1 4 5]
               sorted-v (sort v)
               sorted-v-plus-one (map #(+ 1 %) sorted-v)]
      sorted-v-plus-one)
```

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: Probably the most important reason to me, personally.

Author: goomba#1378
Content: that strikes me as awfully silly

Author: goomba#1378
Content: naming those intermediate values doesn't really do much for you

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: I do like naming things. It's a critical element for me, but it depends on what's going on.

Author: goomba#1378
Content:
```clojure
(-> [2 3 1 4 5]
   (sort)
   (map #(+ 1 %)))
```
I find much nicer

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: Most of my "variables" in other languages are for destructuring and naming things for clarity.

Author: goomba#1378
Content: mhm... but renaming every step in a transformation can be really redundant

Author: goomba#1378
Content: that's kind of like notation for `apply`

Author: goomba#1378
Content:
so 
```Python
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

>>> add(1, 2)
3
>>> add(*[1, 2])
3
```

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: Um, interesting.

Author: goomba#1378
Content: what I just wrote (the "destructuring") is a very non-idiomatic way to write Python

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: Is that for any function?

Author: goomba#1378
Content: yeah that's for any function

Author: goomba#1378
Content:
it would be equivalent to, say, 
```Python
>>> apply(add, [1, 2])
3
```

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: Ohhhh, wait, yeah, it's the deglobbing like in Perl/Ruby

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: @arichiardi Yeah, but, a lot of it ends up being bash because Nix expressions are limited.

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: Whereas Guix fixes that by just using Scheme.

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: So any package can define configs in Scheme.

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: It's all Scheme, even up to and including the init system, and daemon manager.

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: Nix just uses systemd

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: And a whole load of bash.

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: (As far as I saw.)

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: It also means some of the nix expressions have snippets of bash.

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: And aren't purely functional.

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: I think it's an interesting observation that the mailing list traffic has slowed as the mix of hobbyist vs professional in the community seems to have shifted. I think a lot of what is being surfaced in these discussions is just the natural maturing of the language and its ecosystem.

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: We're in a new world where the number of languages just keeps growing so individual languages are not going to follow either the boom or bust trajectories of old -- there are now middle-ground trajectories that are perfectly healthy for languages to follow. Haskell has "avoided success at all costs" and is probably more widespread now than it has ever been (after 25+ years) but no one would claim Haskell is anywhere close to going mainstream (would they?).

Author: hagus#1255
Content: I just spent the majority of today debugging an OOM that ended up being caused by a rogue SQL statement (select * from table with 25 million rows)

Author: hagus#1255
Content: I'm kinda ticked off that all my staring at YourKit and the logs didn't find the problem. There's something deficient here and I need to think about what I'm doing wrong ‚Ä¶

Author: hagus#1255
Content: (I ended up executing forms one by one in the REPL until I noticed one of them never returned)

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: I suspect that sort of OOM would be transient so I'm not sure YourKit would catch it -- it's not like it was a memory leak... as soon as the OOM exception hits, all work building the ResultSet etc would be abandoned and the memory would be released...

Author: hagus#1255
Content: I did manage to catch it in yourkit and I was stumped as to why there was this massive quantity of unreachable memory that wasn't being GC'd even when I forced it

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: (using clojure.java.jdbc, I'd expect the OOM to happen in the doall realizing the transformed result set and for that to then be released as soon as the exception triggered)

Author: hagus#1255
Content: oh I have a lazy resultset that I'm spooling onto a channel

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: Sometimes all the memory in the world just isn't enough... üòÉ

Author: hagus#1255
Content: well I thought I must be doing something crazy in a loop! or holding on to the head of a seq somewhere

Author: hagus#1255
Content: I don't log the SQL statements usually because they can be very large (I create a temporary on-commit-drop table, index it, then join against that. JDBC prepared statements don't enjoy hundreds of thousands of parameters üòâ )

Author: hagus#1255
Content: I think the solution coming to mind is to pray to the effigy of mnygard, asking for forgiveness and the wisdom to wrap this I/O in a circuitbreaker next time

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: As for burning "political capital" @MystickPhoenix sometimes you have to be very careful how you persuade a company to consider alternative tech. Where I work, we looked at Scala first, and took it to production for a small subproject. It was successful to some degree but not "successful enough", so we looked at Clojure next. That was good enough to expand its use over time. Six years later, we're a Clojure-only shop on the back end (although we still have some non-Clojure legacy code).

Author: MetaHertz#1461
Content: I've a question about boot-clj. Is it possible to use mono/.net instead of jvm as backend with boot? Lein allows it (throught a plugin lein-clr).

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: Good question. I don't know anyone using the CLR version of Clojure. I mean, I know _some_ people do use it but it's a very small number.

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: But if JVM-based Leiningen can compile Clojure-CLR then it would be easy to do it with Boot (you'd just have to write a task for it -- which is "just" Clojure code).

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: I guess I'd ask, why would you want to use the CLR version of Clojure? Is there some particular constraint on your environment that requires a non-JVM solution? Or is it just curiosity because you're on Windows?

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: FWIW, there are 64 members in the #clr channel on the Clojurians Slack and there's a clojure-clr mailing list on Google Groups so you'll probably get better answers there.

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: Although I'm on a Windows laptop right now, I don't use Windows for development üòÉ I use Mac for most of my desktop, Linux for deployment, and even on my Windows laptop I use the WSL / Ubuntu setup for dev work üòÉ

Author: hagus#1255
Content: TIL that `when-first` has been missing from my life

Author: ThuglasAdams#7685
Content: i don't understand what that's for?

Author: hagus#1255
Content:
instead of having to write
```clojure
(when (seq some-vec)
  (let [first-element (first some-vec)]
     ; ok now do something with first-element
))
```

Author: hagus#1255
Content: basically if you need to check if something is a non-empty sequence, and if so, do something with the first element

Author: Slackwise#2471
Content: Beautiful.

Author: ThuglasAdams#7685
Content: I think I'm having trouble understanding the macro

Author: ThuglasAdams#7685
Content:
```clojure
(defmacro when-first
  "bindings => x xs

  Roughly the same as (when (seq xs) (let [x (first xs)] body)) but xs is evaluated only once"
  {:added "1.0"}
  [bindings & body]
  (assert-args
     (vector? bindings) "a vector for its binding"
     (= 2 (count bindings)) "exactly 2 forms in binding vector")
  (let [[x xs] bindings]
    `(when-let [xs# (seq ~xs)]
       (let [~x (first xs#)]
           ~@body))))
```

Author: ThuglasAdams#7685
Content: it's like, how is 'x' being used?

Author: hagus#1255
Content: yeah macros are like that üòÉ

Author: hagus#1255
Content: so `bindings` in this case is going to be whatever you passed as the first argument to the macro

Author: hagus#1255
Content: so if you said

Author: hagus#1255
Content:
```clojure
(when-first [first-elem my-vector]
  (println "first-elem was" first-elem))
```

Author: hagus#1255
Content: in the macro code `bindings` will be `[first-elem my-vector]`, literally just a vector of symbols at that stage

Author: hagus#1255
Content: so it's then destructured so that `x` is bound locally to `first-elem` and `xs` is bound locally to `my-vector`

Author: hagus#1255
Content: you can also expand the macro to see what comes out

Author: hagus#1255
Content: straight from our friend @repl-bot

Author: hagus#1255
Content:
```clojure
 (let* [temp4657auto (clojure.core/seq my-vector)] 
  (clojure.core/when temp4657auto 
    (clojure.core/let [xs5205auto temp4657auto] 
      (clojure.core/let [first-elem (clojure.core/first xs5205auto__)]
        (println "first-elem was" first-elem)))))
```

Author: ThuglasAdams#7685
Content: yeah, I need to learn about macro notation

Author: hagus#1255
Content: can anyone explain this?

Author: hagus#1255
Content:
```clojure
  (clojure.walk/prewalk
    #(if (map-entry? %)
       (clojure.tools.trace/trace %)
       %) {:a {:b {:c 456}}})
  ;TRACE: [:a {:b {:c 456}}]
  ;TRACE: [:b {:c 456}]
  ;TRACE: [:c 456]
  ;=> {:a {:b {:c 456}}}

  (clojure.walk/postwalk
    #(if (map-entry? %)
       (clojure.tools.trace/trace %)
       %) {:a {:b {:c 456}}})
  ;=> {:a {:b {:c 456}}}
```

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: Yes, there's a JIRA issue open about it. `postwalk` doesn't preserve `MapEntry` types.

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: https://dev.clojure.org/jira/browse/CLJ-2031

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: (go vote for it @hagus!)

Author: hagus#1255
Content: a bug! so I'm not going crazy üòÉ

Author: hagus#1255
Content: some of the jira stuff is kind of interesting - this kind of bug I'd expect to be a no-brainer, well protected by a test suite, and easy to integrate quickly

Author: hagus#1255
Content: but I see a lot of bugs like this just parked with little action. at least this one is screened in to 1.9

Author: hagus#1255
Content: (and I voted for it üòâ )

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: I think in this case not many people use generic tree walkers -- they write custom walkers instead?

Author: hagus#1255
Content: or use specter or some such. it's true that prewalk and postwalk are pretty limited but they still have an API contract they are supposed to fulfill

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: Well, `postwalk` still _produces_ hash maps -- it just doesn't preserve the specific `MapEntry` type. So it's an edge case a lot of people have not run into. Yet.

Author: hagus#1255
Content: i would love to know more about the decision process ‚Ä¶ this is a classic problem for anyone who vends API. how can you tell who uses it and how important it is? has anyone built functionality that *depends* on the faulty behavior? I'm sure Cognitect have a process of some kind

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: The process is described in detail on the wiki somewhere. With a flow diagram of how JIRA issues are reviewed and implemented.

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: And the Cognitect folks have talked about it fairly extensively in various venues.

Author: seancorfield#3069

Author: seancorfield#3069

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: If you know what your SQL statements are in advance and you want to keep them separate from your Clojure code, HugSQL makes sense. If you need to build your SQL statements dynamically because they involve a lot of conditional logic, then HoneySQL is likely to be a better choice (since you get composability of SQL fragments).

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: For World Singles, HugSQL would really only address a small portion of our SQL usage.

Author: seancorfield#3069
Content: (so it really wouldn't be worth having separation of code and SQL for that small portion)

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content:
Does anyone have a good framework or other advice for working with lots of state in a single atom server-side  in Clojure and/or Clojurescript (server-side)? I have some code where it's going to be better if I keep all my state in a single atom and maintain some kind of push relationship if I can like in clojurescript (Om next, Reagent, Reframe, etc.). It'll be used in a  long-running process that makes extensive use of core.async. I'd like to create something like a reframe subscription that pushes updates at some defined/reasonable frequency to various records (components) and other pieces of code interested in specific queries of that state. Not sure if using any of these more UI-centric libs is a good idea as some of them reference either the DOM or a fake DOM for testing. 

I had thought to just use atoms and watches, but it feels like I'll just be reinventing the wheel with all the management I'll throw on top of it vs. something that already exists. Any suggestions for up-to-date libs that have decent performance? Long story short, I have a lot of code sharing going on between web, server-side, and pure-server apps (in this case), so I'd like to keep the code as similar as possible.

Author: lepistane#2482
Content:
i am not an expert but feels like you are doing something wrong. 
why isnt that data (that you want to put in atom on server side and want to maintain) in database?
maybe datomic would be the way to go? 

cant help u with libraries.
but i feel like you are doing something wrong 
or i am noob and havent understood the question 

maybe just maybe atoms arent way to go but REFS are? 
check them out

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: it is in a database, but it is not efficient to query the database constantly. Moreover, there's an event loop of sorts where I only want changed values, not to requery even memory every time.

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: Regarding datomic, I cannot use datomic for any piece but my main server because there is a client app (desktop) and a server app (user-run/cloud deployable as well) that will not allow me to use Datomic due to licensing/ease of deployment

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: Refs are not necessary in this case either and the problem remains the same with any sort of watches

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: Finally, I need to synchronize my state with remote instances. I do save things in a local, embedded DB, but that is more for efficiency or to sync activity that happened while there was no connectivity. Om-next in essence seems to have some good fits for all this, but it seems to me that the query/update model is in part tied to components and rendering in a UI, so it would take some work to resolve that. Reagent and ratom on the other hand seems like it would work, but again it's more UI focused. There's things like reactive streams that could possibly work but would require a lot of extra work to add some of what things like om next or reframe already do.

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: In summary, having a single source of truth is going to help me a lot rather than sprinkling state into many places (ex: core.async go blocks). Querying an embedded database every 16ms or so is not going to work well so there needs to be minimum an in-memory representation. To a degree again Datomic fits the bill but it is a non-starter since at least several components of my app can run on a user's desktop and/or server(s).

Content: yeah I've mucked around with datascript. That's find if I want querying, but as far as I know doesn't provide any built-in subscription model without some other framework.

Content: I've looked into the funcool beicon project which might work for me

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: as far as the db itself, just being an atom is fine for the in-memory part

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: And I should add that most of this data can be read from another app's UI, but for the purposes of this server-side stuff, it is a simulation of sorts

Author: hswick#4417
Content: wow beicons api seems pretty simple

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: So in essence it's like a browser doing "Render" but render is running the simulation each frame rather than rendering a dom

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: the other data I have is streams, but since some of them are large, I persist those remotely and only temporarily locally

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: for that I'm not so worried about querying, this is more for sim data that is changing like LERPing between values every few seconds

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: so I can do something like LERP some value,  transact the data into an atom/memory DB, and eventually persist it remotely (for loading later/sharing remotely/etc)

Author: hswick#4417
Content: Hmmm i guess i dont get why you would reactive streams on the server and wouldnt just do the calculations and then send the data over a normal websocket

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: but the sim needs the new LERP'd value in a few places and it doesn't make sense to me to constantly every sim frame be doing "get" type operations on a map when the data hasn't always changed

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: because this "is" a server

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: There are first-party servers (remote) which you can save data to if you want, but that's optional

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: And 3rd party servers (user owned), i..e this

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: So these servers are meant to do calculations, allow user defined functions and such, and all kinds of other stuff. There's no requirement to send data remotely if you don't want to, however you give up things like storing giant streams and such of course

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: In the remote case, yes I do communicate over a websocket and fall back to polling. That data gets written to Kafka and eventually cassandra and elasticsearch as well

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: But that's stream data, not this sim data really. Think like values of knobs and sliders and gauges and such that control what is being done to a stream. Stream storage itself is another concern.

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: But I'd like to try to treat everything as a stream if I can because it makes things cleaner and nicer for doing some level of meta-type operations like a stream of UI changes

Author: hswick#4417
Content: sounds to me like you should just treat everything as stream and then sprinkle in the rx streams when you need it for optimization purposes it seems like

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: yeah that was my thought too. I'm just looking to see if there's latest and greatest option besides something like rx.js (which beicon uses)

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: So pulling map keys as I am iterating in some event loop seems the antithesis of that, which is why I wanted something more reactive

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: and given some data can arrive over the websocket, it becomes easier too if I can just feed that into the same change stream and not worry where it came from/how

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: like if you imagine a user in some UI tweaks a knob, that change gets sent eventually to this server doing processing and reads out the underlying value it needs to change how it processes the stream (with some obvious delay)

Author: hswick#4417
Content: from what ive read in clojure community i feel like most people would recommend going with streams + core.async, core.async being used to build whatever specific event loop model you need

Author: hswick#4417
Content: maybe you could just follow this pattern https://github.com/clojure/core.async/wiki/Pub-Sub

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: yeah I'm already using core.async for the things doing the processing

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: you could think of it as a pipeline of processes like unix pipes, each represented by a series of go blocks and connections between them (oversimplifying)

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: So each process needs some parameters (some global, some unique to the process)

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: so it's just a matter of giving the guts of the go-block some value as it is doing something like "go-loop" at various points in the loop where there are local bindings

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: and/or pulling from a channel depending on what the data is

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: but yeah the actual inputs to the processes are just arriving on channels

Author: hswick#4417
Content: i would imagine core.async would cover all those cases, core.async + immutable data structures is latest and greatest üòÜ

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: it pretty much does, like I said it's just a matter of the parameters/settings used to operate on the inputs over time

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: those change over time, so I am just trying to figure out the best way I can get them somewhere, hopefully via push rather than pull

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: and even if I had a go block that was pushing, it still needs to be notified somehow of a change, so it's more about the notification mechanism (ex: subscription) than it is anything else

Author: Sandwich of Unusual Size#2947
Content: building that off watches on an atom works, just my feeling that it is reinventing the wheel

Author: hswick#4417
Content: im not an expert but i think pubsub would solve your problem, or at least some kind of mechanism would solve your problem. I think you have all the libraries (tech) you need just need to find the right design pattern, im sure other people have seen this type of problem before

Author: goomba#1378
Content: anyone want to play "why is my clojure so slow" with me today?

Author: goomba#1378
Content: trying to do some data processing

Author: goomba#1378
Content:
```(defn -main [& args]
  (let [value (slurp (nth files 1020))
        ws (words value)]
    (as-> {} x
        (time (assoc x :bigrams (bigrams ws)))
        (time (assoc x :trigrams (trigrams ws)))
        (time (assoc x :quadgrams (quadgrams ws))))))

"Elapsed time: 1570.11396 msecs"
"Elapsed time: 1957.212454 msecs"
"Elapsed time: 2403.794646 msecs"
```
This seems unreasonable to me

Author: goomba#1378
Content:
```(defn ngrams [n contents]
  (let [ngs (partition n 1 contents)]
    (frequencies ngs)))

(defn bigrams [contents]
  (ngrams 2 contents))

(defn trigrams [contents]
  (ngrams 3 contents))

(defn quadgrams [contents]
  (ngrams 4 contents))
```

Content:
```def ftime(f):
    def fn(*args, **kwargs):
        t0 = time.time()
        res = f(*args, **kwargs)
        t = (time.time() - t0) * 1000
        print(f"Elapsed time: {t:.6f} msecs")
        return res
    return fn
@ftime
def rtest():
    return reduce(lambda x, y: x + [y], range(10000), [])
x = rtest()
Elapsed time: 206.310987 msecs
```

```
(def x (time (reduce #(conj % %2) [] (range 10000))))
"Elapsed time: 3.70408 msecs"
```

Content: Having a swallower stack of seqs and an efficient data struct underneath is a step towards better performance.

Content: well the type of cipher we're trying to break, when decoded, would look something like `ilikekevinbacon`

Author: goomba#1378
Content: so... my initial efforts were to remove all whitespaces and then get the overlapping ngrams

Author: goomba#1378
Content: thus we could do a frequency based attack

Author: goomba#1378
Content: I was provided some frequency tables for bigrams, trigrams, quadgrams, etc, but the unfortunately gibberish strings were being scored above actual english strings

Author: goomba#1378
Content: so I had to consider the possibility that the frequency tables I got weren't adequate and so I did some datamining of project gutenburg and got about 40k books

Author: goomba#1378
Content: then I set about processing them as described above but at 10-15 seconds per book was way to slow, even with massive parallelism

Author: goomba#1378
Content: even if I were to parallelize the ngram crunching it would still bottleneck at about 3.5 seconds per book (with my current implementation) and ended up abandoning it in favor of a Python implementation which made me üò≠

Author: goomba#1378
Content: but without much tuning at all crunching a book in Python took about 0.3 seconds

Author: goomba#1378
Content: so I set up a machine that could crunch 64 books at a time and got through them all in about 1.5 hours

Author: goomba#1378
Content: should also mention that I did substantially more in depth analysis, ngrams were just the start

Author: goomba#1378
Content: also measured words by string length, frequency by character position, intraword letter transition frequencies, interword transition frequencies by both letter and length, and word length frequency

Author: goomba#1378
Content: the whole idea is to update the heuristic to a markov chain using a modified viterbi lattice technique to hopefully provide better probabilistic results

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: so, I've done some testing

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: I think partition is the slow part of your program

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: Your using partition as a sliding window of chars, so its returning a seq of seq of chars.

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: and freqs is hasing each seq of chars into a map.

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: hashing

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: so the ngrams are represented as a seq of chars.

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: its faster to use a string instead

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: so instead of using partition, use a function that returns a seq of strings, where ngrams represented as a string.

Author: Scallions#8493
Content:
`(defn subs-windows
  [n s]
  (map #(subs s % (+ % n))
       (range (- (count s) (dec n)))))
`

Author: Scallions#8493
Content:
```(defn subs-windows
  [n s]
  (map #(subs s % (+ % n))
       (range (- (count s) (dec n)))))

```

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: i wrote this func to replace partition.

Author: Scallions#8493
Content:
so ngrams should become ....

```
(defn ngrams [n contents]
  (let [ngs (subs-windows n contents)]
    (frequencies ngs)))
```

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: If your familiar with transducers, this can be optimized a bit more.

Author: Scallions#8493
Content:
```clojure

(defn subs-windows-educt
  [n s]
  (eduction (map #(subs s % (+ % n)))
            (range (- (count s) (dec n)))))

(defn ngrams3 [n contents]
  (->> contents
       (subs-windows-educt n)
       (frequencies)))

```

Author: zcaudate#9919
Content: @alice: so you want to have it destructure params?

Author: zcaudate#9919
Content: I see what you want to do... like  `(defresponse create-user ...)`

Author: zcaudate#9919
Content: it's a little dangerous to have `req` like that and to be honest, it's probably better if you don't use a macro

Author: zcaudate#9919
Content: this should work:

Author: zcaudate#9919
Content:
```
(defmacro jason-response [name bindings body]
    `(defn ~name [{:keys [~'params] :as ~'req}]
       (let [~(apply hash-map bindings) ~'params]
         ~@body)))
```

Author: zcaudate#9919
Content: you can check by calling macroexpand-1

Author: zcaudate#9919
Content:
```
(macroexpand-1 '(jason-response create-user [email :email password :password]
                                  [email password]))

  => (clojure.core/defn create-user [{:as req, :keys [params]}]
       (clojure.core/let [{email :email, password :password} params] email password))
```

Author: zcaudate#9919
Content:
```
  (create-user {:params {:email "hello@world.com" :password "secret"}})
  => ["hello@world.com" "secret"]
```

Author: zcaudate#9919
Content:
I forgot the `&` before `body`:
```
(defmacro jason-response [name bindings & body]
    `(defn ~name [{:keys [~'params] :as ~'req}]
       (let [~(apply hash-map bindings) ~'params]
         ~@body)))
```

Author: zcaudate#9919
Content:
I would advise against doing that and just using :
```
(defn create-user [{:as req, :keys [params]}]
       (let [{email :email, password :password} params]
         ...
         ...))
```

Author: srasu#0042
Content: So the book Clojure for the Brave and True suggests that the use function and :use reference in the ns macro are considered frowned-upon in production code. Is that still valid, and why is that the case?

Author: bbss#6837
Content: @srasu when you use use, definitions from that namespace get imported as if it's in your current namespace

Author: bbss#6837
Content: this means that you can have name collisions

Author: bbss#6837
Content: which can cause problems obviously.

Author: bbss#6837
Content: it's more for when you're hacking around and you don't want to manage importing and deleting obsolete imports

Author: bbss#6837
Content: does that make sense or would you like an example?

Author: srasu#0042
Content: That makes sense.

Author: Quixoticelixer#6239
Content: i wrote my first useful macro 1

Author: Quixoticelixer#6239
Content:
```clj


(def command-file (slurp "data.json"))

(defn read-data []
  (->> (json/parse-string command-file)
       (seq)
       (map (fn [data] (create-command (symbol (first data)) (last data))))
       (map var-get)
       (vec)))

(defmacro create-command [name result]
  (let [name-sym (gensym "name")
        type-sym (gensym "type")
        data-sym (gensym "data")]
    `(defn ~name-sym [~type-sym ~data-sym] (discord/answer-command ~data-sym ~name (str ~result)))))
```

Author: Lilly Knight#1014

```clojure
(let [...]
  (defn some-func [...]
      ....))
```

Content: Pardon the shitty formatting

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Hello everyone! Does anyone have a library which well organized or an article/blogpost which outlines the pitfalls of designing libraries?

Author: srasu#0042
Content: I haven't really seen any. Biggest thing I can think of that I've seen in a bunch of talks is that once people start using your library you have to move away from making breaking changes to making growing changes. Which open-source projects often break this rule because of how few people are involved in making changes.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Breaking changes being something like removing or renaming functions, changing what parameters they take, or reducing how much or what kind of data is returned from a given function call. Growing changes being things like adding new functions, adding how much is returned from existing functions, adding new (optional) arguments (or arities) to functions, etc.

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: Rich talked about this in his spec-culation keynote.

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oyLBGkS5ICk

Author: Scallions#8493
Content:
Its more about how you should maintain a library.
Basically, try to never make breaking changes. Accrete new stuff. Relax your library's contraints. Namespaces are cheap.

Author: Quixoticelixer#6239
Content: I think early it is okay to break stuff

Author: Quixoticelixer#6239
Content: and infact shuold try to break stuff as much as possible but then come to a point where you don't break anything unless it is super duper important

Author: srasu#0042
Content: I agree that breaking things before release is fine. So did Rich actually. It's just that you can't just say "Oh, I'm calling this 'alpha' so I can make breaking changes whenever I want" since even if you're in "alpha" you can still have people who depend on your code.

Author: hswick#4417
Content: you know or just name shit properly the first time

Author: srasu#0042
Content: I mean naming stuff right is all fine and dandy, but what if you suddenly figure out your system is set up wrong internally and you have to change the external api in order for it to be workable?

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
So it just sounds like something that you're passing a var to is expecting not a var, but what's contained at the var instead. I don't have much experience calling Clojure from Java, but maybe you need to deref the `Clojure.var("clojail.testers", "secure-tester")` part somehow. What you're currently doing is equivalent to this:
```clojure
(def sb (sandbox #'clojail.testers/secure-tester))
```
But what you really want to be doing is this:
```clojure
(def sb (sandbox @#'clojail.testers/secure-tester))
```

Content:
Here it is in text form so you can copy-paste:

(defn multiples [curr max]

  (if (or (= 0 (rem curr 3)) (= 0 (rem curr 5)))

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Place the function before main

Author: AltLock#5724
Content: Just realized this xD

Author: AltLock#5724
Content: Stupid me. Why is this necessary if I may ask?

Author: AltLock#5724
Content: Clojure gets compiled, yes?

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Yes, I believe so.

Author: jshah#3301
Content: There is a way to declare functions before hand at which point the order doesn't matter

Author: AltLock#5724
Content: Ah. I'll look that up. Thank you very much. I didn't expect this to be a thing, I thought the compiler would go through the whole file first and understand that the function exists.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: It is compiled, yes. The thing is though, it's a single-pass compiler. That means things are defined sequentially. Kind of like in ye-olde C days (but with no headers). I'm not aware of the specific reason for this, but I think it's mostly just because it creates a simpler compiler.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: What you can do though is to use the `declare` macro to let the compiler know that they are defined (but without creating a base binding) and that it can be used before it gets `def`ed

Author: AltLock#5724
Content: Thanks for the explanation, I'll just move my -main function to the bottom of my sourcefiles. I prefer them to be at the top to get an overview of what the program does, but I prefer less bugs than more because of it(possibly forgetting to declare a function)

Author: srasu#0042
Content: One thing that you'll find as you program more and more in clojure is that you generally want to read your code from the inside out on the small scale, but on the large scale (even for just deeper nested calls that get separated into lines) it's frequently good to just read your code from the bottom up. That way you can see things as they are used, instead of seeing all the details without an overview of what's trying to be accomplished.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Honestly it took me longer to wrap my head around immutability than it should have. But that's mostly from the near-decade I spent doing imperative, object-oriented code before I got started with Clojure. That had really worn me down to the point where I was basically fed up with programming. I started Clojure though and it made it fun again. Even when I'm using other languages.

Author: AltLock#5724
Content: It makes reading both Ruby and Clojure really easy

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Yeah, I definitely agree. Clojure has a good emphasis on readability over other lisps.

Author: AltLock#5724
Content: About immutability, I've ran into the same today. I was trying to append items to a list recursively, it really takes me some brainpower to get it working and looking nicely.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: This is true. It requires a whole different way of thinking.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Which is why I'm so glad that Clojure tries to be readable. You tend to do so many things that are foreign to programmers who haven't done things functionally before that having it be more difficult to read could just be too much.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: And I personally really like it since it means I don't have to spend any real brain power on parsing what the code is supposed to do (unlike when I code in ALGOL-descended languages), so instead I can focus entirely on the difficulty of wrapping my head around the problem space. I have to say that understanding transducer factory factories is a little hard when you're still trying to think in an imperative manner, so readability is a must. XD

Author: AltLock#5724
Content: BTW; I had a question. Is clojurescript exactly the same as clojure in the syntax sense? Or are there catches I need to know about?

Author: srasu#0042
Content: So ClojureScript has a few minor differences. There are a few absent things, like the only reference types are atoms. Then there's a slight change in the require syntax where you have to refer macros separately from everything else.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: And the interop syntax is slightly different, since there's a different host language. But for the most part it's the same, yes.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Tons of code runs equally well on both runtimes, which is why the .cljc format exists. It's there for code that runs on both clojure and clojurescript, plus it has some support for compiler flags to use different forms depending on the host it's running with.

Author: AltLock#5724
Content: I suppose it runs on 'itself', so that's the benefit and of course the reason why it is even possible to have Clojure on two different platforms.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Well, I wouldn't really say it runs on itself. That would the Clojure in Clojure project, which eventually got renamed to the tools.analyzer and tools.emitter libraries.

Author: hswick#4417
Content: Can you give an example?

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content:
So instead of ```clojure
[a b]
``` 
you could do something like ```clojure
[1 b]
```

Content: Would a be a different type than 1? Maybe pattern matching is what you are looking for

Content: Would it matter?

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content: I want to do one thing when a is 1 and another when a is not 1

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: You can use multimethods to accomplish this.

Author: hswick#4417
Content: In terms of the arguments for the function probably not. Sounds like you could use pattern matching or a cond expression or multimethods. Or simple if statements

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content: I know I could just use simple if statements. I was just curious if there was a feature like this as other languages support that. Haskell comes to mind for one.

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content: Multimethods is definitely not what I'm looking for

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: I don't think clojure has something like this builtin.

Author: Scallions#8493
Content: core.match library is the closest thing to this. I imagine if you want to replicate this feature, you would need to write a macro that combines `fn` and `match` from core.match.

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content: Ok, I'll take a look at that. Thanks

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content: Doesn't seem to be it either. I want to call functions when a is 1 or not, not return a data structure

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content:
Here' a Haskell example of the kind of thing I'm trying to do:
```haskell
factorial :: (Integral a) => a -> a  
factorial 0 = 1  
factorial n = n * factorial (n - 1)
```

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content: So yes, pattern matching is correct, but with functions or values being returned

Author: HactarCE#5314
Content: It's probably simplest just to use `cond`

Author: HactarCE#5314
Content:
E.g.
```Clojure
(defn factorial [n]
 (cond
  (zero? n) 1
  :else (* n (factorial (dec n)))))
```

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content: Ok, that works for two conditions. What about more than two?

Author: HactarCE#5314
Content: Keep adding more clauses

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content: Oh, ok

Author: HactarCE#5314
Content:
```Clojure
(defn factorial [n]
 (cond
  (zero? n) 1
  (< n 0) nil
  (<= n 2) n
  :else (* n (factorial (dec n)))))
```

Author: WhoNeedszZz#9017
Content: Figured there was a way to do it. Thanks

Author: HactarCE#5314
Content: Np

Author: HactarCE#5314
Content: The `:else` clause is optional, I think

Author: HactarCE#5314
Content: probably just returns `nil` unless it's included

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Hi everyone! Quick question: if I wanted to access `:c` then why doesn't `(get-in [:a [:b [:c]]] [:a :b])` work?

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Because :a and :b are not the keys for that set of vectors.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: While technically vectors are associative datastructures, they associate indexes to values, not keys to values.

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Ohhhhhhh!

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
So if you wanted to do that you'd actually do this:
```clojure
(get-in [:a [:b [:c]]] [1 1 0])
```

Author: jshah#3301
Content: That's why I was confused. I saw that vectors implemented association but didn't realize it was between indexes and values üòõ

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Yes.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: So last night I translated the classic macro `once-only` into clojure. That was an undertaking.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Not so much the writing of it itself (though that was definitely a challenge, and would have been outright impossible for me without cider's macroexpand feature), but the understanding of what was going on with all the splicing. Just wow.

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
For any interested, here's the macro:
```clojure
(defmacro once-only [[& names] & body]
  (let [gensyms (repeatedly (count names) gensym)]
    `(let [~@(mapcat (fn [g] `(~g (gensym))) gensyms)]
       `(let ~(into [] (apply concat ~(mapv (fn [g n] ``(~~g ~~n)) gensyms names)))
          ~(let [~@(mapcat (fn [n g] `(~n ~g)) names gensyms)]
             ~@body)))))
```
I'm more than willing to offer a basic explanation of what's going on for anyone interested.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: There's a _lot_ to unpack in those six lines.

Author: lepistane#2482
Content:
that's kind of you.
lets hear it 

i am not familiar with classic macros
where did you learn about them? 
any good resources? 

why is it used?

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
"classic macro" isn't really a defined subset of macros, it's simply how I'm referring to one of the more advanced commonly-used macros in other lisp dialects. This particular macro I found source for in Practical Common Lisp, and I spent the evening last night translating it.
This particular macro is used in the writing of macros where you want an argument to be evaluated precisely once.
The way that this works is by having the macro defined using this macro introduce a let into the using code which binds gensyms to the value of evaluating the argument, and then the macro allows you while writing your macro to refer to these new gensyms under the original names.
For example:
```clojure
(defmacro testing [form]
  (once-only [form]
    `[~form ~form]))
```
Would expand to this (conceptually, in reality it's somewhat messier due to the machinery for generating the binding vector):
```clojure
(defmacro testing [form]
  (let [G__001 (gensym)]
    `(let [~G__001 ~form]
      ~(let [form G__001]
        [form form]))))
```
And using said macro will expand to this:
```clojure
(testing (do (println "Hello from the macro!") (+ 2 2)))
(let [G__002 (do (println "Hello from the macro!" ) (+ 2 2))]
  [G__002 G__002])
```
Which will seem a little cryptic at first, but what it does is allows the the macro creator to refer to the forms using their original symbols repeatedly within the body of their macro, without worrying about them being evaluated more than once.
So for this example, without using the once-only macro this would have instead expanded and evaluated the println multiple times, however because of the once-only macro the println is evaluated exactly once, but the value returned from the containing form is used multiple times.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: @lepistane

Author: srasu#0042
Content: So far all of this could be done without the complex mapcat and into machinery, but all that becomes required once you allow multiple arguments to be within the vector of forms to be evaluated precisely once.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: And finally because this is a hygenic macro that is itself assissting in the creation of other hygenic macros, we have to use gensym both inside the main body of the macro, as well as within the body of the macro that is being written using `once-only`

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
I've shared at least one on here before. I'm currently working on two main projects that I can share between my university work (also have an application being developed for a startup, but I can't share that for obvious reasons). Those being discljord, a library for creating discord bots in Clojure. It's currently functional, though ugly. I want to finish up my state system for it and then add a layer of syntactic abstraction to make it nicer to use.
https://github.com/IGJoshua/discljord
Then I'm also working on a small game engine that's pure Clojure over top of OpenGL using lwjgl's bindings for OpenGL, OpenAL, etc. 
That's available here:
https://github.com/IGJoshua/handmade-clojure
On that one I've been working on getting the window and mesh rendering to work well (although I haven't had the time to get super far yet), and I'm just about at the time where I want to start making some minor decisions about how I want to model the engine, and I've been debating between an Entity Component System and a kind of event-based reactive system. I might try a bit of both soon to see which one works better.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Notably in order to have the rendering engine have nice syntax for the lower level, I created an updated version of the old clojure contrib library that alters the import-static macro to use ^:const on the values it generates, and to include an "import all" so that I can just do an import of a class from LWJGL and use the functions from OpenGL directly.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: I didn't spend the time to figure out how the def-proxied macros work for that library though, so I didn't get a working version of def-proxied-all. Although I did update def-proxied to use ^:const as well

If it turns out to be real good I'll use it, but so far I generally want either the speed and clarity of C, or the expressiveness of Lisp. I rarely like any of the middle ground languages. Author: Quixoticelixer#6239
Content: But to be honest the biggest problem I am having is with design

Author: Quixoticelixer#6239
Content: How to think about a problem before putting it into a computer program

Author: Quixoticelixer#6239
Content: But I think the best solution to that is to program more

Author: srasu#0042
Content: For sure. Honestly I've found the more I program stuff, the more programming is the best way to design it. Which is codified in the idea of "compression oriented programming". Basically do things in the stupidest way you can think of, and then once you start doing it multiple times extract it. It's one of the simplest ways you can start to do code reuse, and allows you to organically see where your project is going and start to refactor to make it work better once you have a good idea of what the requirements actually are, instead of speculating wildly about what you might need.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: It's surprising to me that it's taken me so long to come to that conclusion, given that I've been programming about 6-12 hours a day for the past 10 years.

Author: Quixoticelixer#6239
Content: Yeah, how ever I think that once you get more experience you can guess and estimate stuff better, and design things right from the start instead of bushwacking

Author: Quixoticelixer#6239
Content: and it varies a lot in different problems and domains

Author: srasu#0042
Content: That's the thing, I've thought that too for years. Even when I've been working on a project in a similar genre to something I've done a dozen times before, it always surprises me that I have no idea what the requirements actually end up being. So in my experience _so far_ I've found that it's better to avoid abstracting too early even if you think you know what's going to need to be abstracted.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: And I'm saying that personally I want to go _back_ to bushwacking after spending several about 4 years doing just that, and then another 6 doing so-called "good design" whether that was OO design for the first 5 years of that, or "module" style design like I have been doing for the last year.

Author: Quixoticelixer#6239
Content: I think that abstraction is necessarily the same as design though, and like you describe it is very easy to think you will probably need to abstract something and then it turns out that was a terrible idea

Author: srasu#0042

Content: @Quixoticelixer After spending some time and thought it seems like the main thing that I can predict discljord needing right now is coverage of dicord's HTTP API.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: The other big thing I want to do with it is start making a somewhat complex bot with it and start ironing out pain points. Since I was premature with how I wanted to do state, I think I'm going to rip that out entirely and then start building a bot, and start making niceties for what I start figuring out is needed. The biggest barrier in the way of being able to make that bot though is said coverage of the HTTP api.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Any actual bot-related state, sure. I'm keeping that. The main thing I want to pitch right now is the idea of "bot wide" and "guild specific" state because my api for it was absolute trash. I want to use the bot a bit and manage my own state for a bit so that I can see how the api could help manage it.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: That way I don't make assumptions about what's good, and then end up totally wrong like last time.

Either that or just leave all saving to the user, which I don't personally like.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Just pushed another change. Surprised it took me this long to do since it's such a major workflow thing. I wrapped the calls to the event listeners dispatched in discljord.bots in a try/catch block that will print the exception to `*err*` and won't crash the thread. This way if a listener throws an exception you can just keep working on it, re-evaluate the function, and test it immediately instead of having to restart the bot. Major workflow improvement.

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
I'm thinking that after playing with it for a bit that regexes may be a good way to do commands since commands are supposed to be fairly simple, rather than complex grammars. I plan to make sure that there are lower-level facilities if regex isn't enough for a specific bot, but it'll likely be the default way of making commands. Although I might make another layer on top of that so that people working with the api don't even have to go down to the regex level if they don't like.
I just uploaded the first macro that'll play into that, since frequently with systems like that you'd like it to try to match certain predicates in order until it finds one that it matches, and then not try any more.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Yeah. Right now the low-level way to do it is to receive the :message-create event which is converted from json to edn before it's shipped off to the listener. However I'm thinking I want to make another layer overtop of that since often what a bot will want to do with a message-create is just to use it for commands instead of scanning it for offensive stuff or doing caps checks like a mod bot might. So I want people to be able to have like a generic "commands" api, plus the regular listener api.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: I mean if you're determined to have it work _just_ like an atom, then just write a lower-level java class that implements the same functionality as an atom. Otherwise, I'd recommend determining an interface that works best for how your database is actually backed. But I might be in a minority here because I generally don't recommend abstracting things too much (in spite of doing it myself, it's a habit I'm trying to get out of).

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Dang it. One of the few times I want a dynamic var that acts like they do in common lisp, only to be swatted down by the fact that I can't use set! on a root binding. >.>

Author: sarna#3904
Content: what are dynamic vars?

Author: sarna#3904
Content: if you don't mind explaining

Author: sarna#3904
Content: are they globals? ü§î

Author: srasu#0042
Content: They are globals, but they have dynamic scope.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Which means that you can effectively change them in a way that reaches down into calls to change how they function.

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
So for example:
```clojure
(binding [*out* *err*]
  (println "Hello, this is an error!"))
```
This will rebind the dynamic var `*out*` from standard output to the value of the dynamic var `*err*` which by default is standard error. So this would print out "Hello, this is an error!" to standard error.

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
I wanted to do something like so:
```clojure
(binding [*log-file* "test.txt"]
  (log "Hello, world!"))
```
That in and of itself is easy enough to do, but setting up a default value for it like so unfortunately doesn't work:
```clojure
(defn init-logging
  [filename]
  (set! *log-file* filename))
```
If this worked, you'd be able to set a default logging file, and then not need to wrap each call to log in a `binding` form. There are ways around this with a lexically-scoped `atom` to store the default values, but I wish that I could just `set!` the root value of a var.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: @sarna

Author: sarna#3904
Content: oh üëÄ thanks for going in depth üôè

Author: srasu#0042
Content: No problem.

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
Oh and for reference to create them you use this:
```clojure
(def ^:dynamic *var-name* initial-value)
```
It has to be surrounded by asterisks like that.

Author: sarna#3904
Content: ü§î interesting

Author: srasu#0042
Content: That's an old convention from back in common lisp. *var-name* was a dynamic var, while +var-name+ was a constant. We kept the convention for asterisks, but we upgraded it to an actual compiler warning to not follow that convention.

Author: sarna#3904
Content: makes sense

Content:
I'd be _far_ more comfortable taking up a large project with Clojure than Python, but that's just because I have more experience with Clojure.
Clojure has a lot of really cool features, some of which are very difficult or impossible to replicate in most other languages, so if you want to benefit from them, I'd fully recommend starting with something smaller. For example, my first project with Clojure was a graphical version of the Game of Life using seesaw. That was my first real project with it. Took probably 2 days or so between classes.
Since then I've moved on to far more advanced projects, like an OpenGL rendering engine, and a partially-complete discord api for clojure. So I'd highly recommend doing something like that instead in your free time, rather than going for something so large immediately.

Content:
Gah, this is really frustrating. @Quixoticelixer would you be willing to take a peek at connection.clj?
I ran into an error today that I'm stumped on. The stability of connections with discord servers is really low, they're having disconnects all the time. I just tried to make sure that the bot would try to reconnect when it's passed a 1001 stop code so that would hopefully fix some things, and it gave me some odd things today when I used it. Take a look at this segment of the log:
```text
Connected!
Sending connection packet. Resume: nil
Connection closed. code: 1006
message: WebSocket Read EOF
Read an EOF, reconnecting.
Causes for reconnect: (End of file)
Attempting resume? true
Opening socket during reconnect
Connected!
Sending connection packet. Resume: true
Connection closed. code: 1001
message: Shutdown
Stop code 1001, reconnecting
Causes for reconnect: (Error 1001)
Attempting resume? true
Causes for reconnect: (Invalid session)
Attempting resume? false
Opening socket during reconnect
Opening socket during reconnect
Connected!
Sending connection packet. Resume: false
Connected!
Sending connection packet. Resume: true
Connection closed. code: 4005
message: Already authenticated.
Closing message proc
...
```
Any idea why it would do two reconnects like that?

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Laziness is really useful when you're trying to deal with large datasets and aren't working with side effects.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Laziness being the default can be annoying when you're trying to map with side effects and the repl realizes them and you forget to put a `doall` into your code for it. XD

Author: I Al Istannen#1564
Content: and then goes on with passing them to the caller

Author: Odie#2665
Content: well, lazy seqs definitely has its performance penalties... kind of depends on how "performance critical" a piece of code is...

Author: Odie#2665
Content: but then again, we're usually working with persistent data structures that are already somewhat "slower"...

Author: Odie#2665
Content: it's just a tradeoff...

Author: srasu#0042
Content: This is also true, lazy seqs are not the most efficient things, and they also aren't as lazy as they might be in haskell. They tend to "chunk" instead of going in clean increments of one.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Yes, it is good for performance, reduces overhead of laziness, but it's still less performant than doing it all directly, however if you're working with huge data sets laziness is still better.

Author: voltecrus#7692
Content: A Map is a collection that maps keys to values. Two different map types are provided - hashed and sorted. Hash maps require keys that correctly support hashCode and equals. Sorted maps require keys that implement Comparable, or an instance of Comparator. Hash maps provide faster access (log32N hops) vs (logN hops), *but sorted maps are, well, sorted*.

Author: mandm4s#5333
Content:
I often see people who want to wrap something in a vector if it is not already one. Does anyone know if there is a core function that does this already? Something like the following works, but if it already exists in core I don't want to define it in a project and include it throughout each namespace. 
```
(fn [x] (if (vector? x) x [x])) 
```

Author: lepistane#2482
Content: https://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/vector

Author: lepistane#2482
Content: what is your use case?

Author: mandm4s#5333
Content:
right, so clojure.core/vector will put an element into a vector, but it will also put a vector inside of a vector. I'm wondering if there is a core function to only put 'x' in a vector if x itself is not a vector. 
```
(defn into-vector [x] (if (vector? x) x [x])

(into-vector 1) => [1] ;; 1 is not in a vector, so it wraps it in one. 
(into-vector [1]) => [1] ;; The input is already a vector, so it just returns it as is. 
```
Is there a built in function that accomplishes what into-vector does above? I don't have a specific use case right now, I've just seen this sort of thing being done in many places and wondering if there is a better way to do it.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: If you haven't been using Clojure long and are coming from Java, C#, etc., then maybe it's that hash maps can't be modified in place? If you modify the hash map but don't return and assign it back into the original place then it won't change. You'll just thrash the garbage collector since you'll make a new modified hash map and then lose it into the ether.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: @ninjacop

(1 2)```

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
```clojure
(require '[clojure.core.async :as a])
(defn deref-async
  [fut]
  (a/go @fut))

(let [n 2]
  (map deref-async (take n (repeatedly #(future (Thread/sleep 2000))))))
```

Author: srasu#0042
Content: @![Wys] Juzi

Author: ![Wys] Juzi#1035
Content: oh

Author: ![Wys] Juzi#1035
Content: deref-async

Author: ![Wys] Juzi#1035
Content: using go channels

Author: ![Wys] Juzi#1035
Content: lmao

Author: srasu#0042
Content: deref-async isn't a thing anywhere, but this actually does what you want. It even gives you a way to get values back out.

Author: ![Wys] Juzi#1035
Content: i guess

Author: ![Wys] Juzi#1035
Content: thanks

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Because deref-async will even return a channel, which if you do a take on the channel, it will block and wait for the return value.

Author: ![Wys] Juzi#1035
Content: ü§î

Author: srasu#0042
Content: So this map will return a sequence of channels which will each have a single item put onto them - the return value of the future.

Author: ![Wys] Juzi#1035
Content: but then when i call the values

Author: ![Wys] Juzi#1035
Content: wont that block ?

Author: donderdag#4004
Content: if you use `<!!` it will, but if you use `<!` or `take!` it will not

Author: srasu#0042
Content: yes, but the thing is, that'll wait till the individual task is done. It won't wait on all tasks. This solution will only wait 2000 milliseconds, it won't wait 4 seconds

Author: srasu#0042
Content: and even `<!` conceptually use blocking. It's just parking which means it doesn't actually tie up a runtime thread.

Author: donderdag#4004
Content: right, but it can only be done within a go block, so it's effectively non-blocking

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
So for example:
```clojure
(require '[clojure.core.async :as a])
(defn deref-async
  "Takes a future and gets its result on a separate logical thread, and returns a channel on which the result will eventually be put"
  [fut]
  (a/go @fut))

(defn promise-all
  "Takes a sequence of futures, and runs them asynchronously, returning a sequence of their values"
  [seq]
  (map <!! (map deref-async seq)))
```

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
For those more experienced with spec, how would you go about making a spec that defines a square vector? I've gotten this far, but I can't figure out how I could make sure the count of each of the vectors is the same as the count of the outer one. At least without just making a custom function for it.
```clojure
(s/def ::tile (s/nilable #{:black :white}))
(s/def ::board (s/coll-of (s/coll-of ::tile :kind vector?)
                          :kind vector?))
```
I know I could do it like so, but it feels a little weird and doesn't give good error output if I call explain:
```clojure
(s/def ::tile (s/nilable #{:black :white}))

(defn board?
  [b]
  (and
   (vector? b)
   (every? vector? b)
   (let [size (count b)]
     (every? #(= (count %) size)
             b))
   (every?
    (partial s/valid? ::tile)
    (flatten b))))

(s/def ::board board?)
```

Content:
@srasu I think you are asking for something like this?:

uses core.async

```(def state (atom {:running? false}))

(defn init! [my-chan]
  (swap! state assoc :running? true)
  (thread (while true (do-something (<!! my-chan)))))
```

Although I would add some more logic if you would like to make the thread interruptable/terminateable

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Working more and more with spec. Rich spoke of some of the amazing potential of spec, but didn't give examples of it fulfilling that potential, so I'm left clueless on how to make a function which takes a parameter that is a collection of any spec, and returns a value conforming to the same spec.

Author: Grant#5854
Content:
```(defn my-func [x] (do-something x))

(s/def ::my-spec (s/or :name string? :id int?))

(s/fdef my-func
  :args (s/cat :x (s/coll-of ::my-spec))
  :ret (s/coll-of ::my-spec))```

Author: Grant#5854
Content: or do you mean something else @srasu

Author: srasu#0042
Content: I mean where you don't know what spec they will conform to at compile time, only that the argument and return will conform to the same one. Like a type variable in haskell.

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
```
(defn my-func [x _] (do-something x))

(s/fdef my-func
  :args (s/cat :x (s/coll-of any?) :spec s/spec)
  :ret any?
  :fn (s/and #(s/valid (:spec (:args %)) (:ret %))
             #(s/valid (s/coll-of (:spec (:args %))) (:args %))))
```

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Like this, but without having to pass the spec that the args conform to

Author: srasu#0042
Content: I get the feeling there's no way to do this generically.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: I'm currently programming go for fun, and using spec as much as I can. I am making a "square vector" spec constructor that takes a spec and then ensures that the passed argument is a vector of vectors, all with the same length as the outer vector. All the elements of the sub-vectors must conform to a passed spec (in this case, `::tile`). I also have a generator that takes a spec that has a generator, and will generate such a vector.

```
I'm trying to express this in spec.

Author: donderdag#4004
donderdag#4004
Content:
```clj
=> (doc shutdown-agents)
-------------------------
clojure.core/shutdown-agents
([])
  Initiates a shutdown of the thread pools that back the agent
  system. Running actions will complete, but no new actions will be
  accepted```

Author: donderdag#4004
Content:
if you look at the source for `future`, it does reuse the Agent system:

```clj
=> (source future)
(defmacro future
  "Takes a body of expressions and yields a future object that will
  invoke the body in another thread, and will cache the result and
  return it on all subsequent calls to deref/@. If the computation has
  not yet finished, calls to deref/@ will block, unless the variant of
  deref with timeout is used. See also - realized?."
  {:added "1.1"}
  [& body] `(future-call (^{:once true} fn* [] ~@body)))
nil
=> (source future-call)
(defn future-call
  "Takes a function of no args and yields a future object that will
  invoke the function in another thread, and will cache the result and
  return it on all subsequent calls to deref/@. If the computation has
  not yet finished, calls to deref/@ will block, unless the variant
  of deref with timeout is used. See also - realized?."
  {:added "1.1"
   :static true}
  [f]
  (let [f (binding-conveyor-fn f)
        fut (.submit clojure.lang.Agent/soloExecutor ^Callable f)]
    (reify
     clojure.lang.IDeref
     (deref [_] (deref-future fut))
     clojure.lang.IBlockingDeref
     (deref
      [_ timeout-ms timeout-val]
      (deref-future fut timeout-ms timeout-val))
     clojure.lang.IPending
     (isRealized [_] (.isDone fut))
     java.util.concurrent.Future
      (get [_] (.get fut))
      (get [_ timeout unit] (.get fut timeout unit))
      (isCancelled [_] (.isCancelled fut))
      (isDone [_] (.isDone fut))
      (cancel [_ interrupt?] (.cancel fut interrupt?)))))
nil```

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
I'm thinking of trying to implement a lisp-y wrapper around bullet, and something that's occurred to me is that if I want to have clojure data represent the physics objects, then I need to store the id's of objects and similar information about them that's needed for the actual physics representation, but at the same time I want all that data to be transcient. It shouldn't be written to file if I try to print the data, and I don't want it to be in the main return of the function.
Since I want this to be an apparently pure function, I decided to investigate some things that I could do in order to get it to work properly.
The obvious first thought is that for each time you call the update function, it should create a new physics world in which to simulate everything, and then it would return pure clojure data representing the output of the world. While this could work in theory, I can't imagine that it would be fast to create a world, create tons of physics primitives, run the simulation for one time step, and then delete it all. So I've started thinking about how I could cache information.

Author: srasu#0042
Content:
I was thinking that I could associate the kind of information I need (such as ID's of objects and the world etc) as metadata on the clojure data which represents the objects. That means that whenever you pass in a bit of clojure data it would look to see if there is a world that's been created for that data, and then look through each object and if it has an existing object in the physics world just update it, and if it doesn't, create a new one. Next it would do a physics step, and finally update the clojure data with the new metadata and data.
This way it should act like a pure function, in that it will appear as if it is doing the total amount of work required, but instead it will in fact be caching a lot of information to increase the speed.
Now, as I look at this solution I see one major issue. How do I account for releasing this data? When the garbage collector runs it may eventually eat the data of a physics world, but that world won't have been deleted since it would be foreign memory. I might be able to solve this with weak pointers and a spun off thread, but that feels a little gross to me.

Author: ![Wys] Juzi#1035
Content: i believe you can use https://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/transient

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Yes, but the issue that I feel like I'd run into is the inability to call some kind of destructor when the object is garbage collected.

Author: donderdag#4004
Content: @srasu could you use https://github.com/clojure/core.memoize or https://github.com/clojure/core.cache ?

Author: lsenjov#4288
Content: You shouldn't have to manually call the gc (although you can if you really want with a system call).

Author: lsenjov#4288
Content: The gc will be automatically called many times through the process, as each java object "garden" isn't a monolith by design

Author: lsenjov#4288
Content: Oh right, invalidating your cache is what you're looking for

Author: lsenjov#4288
Content: Core.cache may not be a bad choice, it has a custom limit on how many objects to store

Author: lsenjov#4288
Content: Or are you attempting to store everything in play with the cache, then remove when it's destroyed?

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Hi everyone, how can I handle data from various sources and have it conform to a specification? Suppose, I have data about cars from three different sources which provides the same like car color, name, type etc., however, the JSON is different for each. I want to be able to take the different JSON and convert it a specification.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: I'd have three functions, and depending on the source call them. Make three different specs for the parsed input data, and make transformation functions to move from one of those to the actual car spec.

Author: donderdag#4004
Content:
^

you can use clojure.spec or plumatic/schema for that

Author: srasu#0042
Content: You definitely can make things too generic. I think this would be one of those cases.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: if you tried to encapsulate that all in one function.

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Yea, I had a similar approach to the one you mentioned.

Author: jshah#3301
Content: I figured there would be some library üòõ

Author: jshah#3301
Content: But I suppose as donderdag mentions, we can use spec or something?

Author: srasu#0042
Content: A library to transform data from an unknown format to an unknown format? XD

Author: srasu#0042
Content: You can use spec for some basic parsing of data.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: Using conform.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: But it's not likely to be as flexible as you need.

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Hmmm, right.

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Yea, I was thinking I can define the spec for each response and then define the spec for what I want ultimately and then magic!

Author: jshah#3301
Content: haha

Author: srasu#0042
Content: I mean you'd have to have some way of mapping from one part of a spec to another part of a different spec. I can't imagine that using a library for it would be easier than just making a couple of transform functions. Not unless you can make a programatic way of defining the mapping.

Author: srasu#0042
Content: at which point it'd only be worth it if you had to do hundreds of _different_ transformations, not just the same transformation multiple times.

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Ahhh, okay. Better to go with a simpler approach, as you suggested.

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Thanks for the quick help!

Author: srasu#0042
Content: No problem! Let me know if you need anything else. I'm pretty happy to help whenever I can.

Author: jshah#3301
Content: Awesome! Thanks üòÑ Maybe, if you're up for it, I can show you the solution once I've implemented it?

Content: Sure
